STRATEGIC CONTEXT AND RATIONALE
1. Country and sector issues
1. Avian Influenza the global dimension. The continuing outbreaks o f highly pathogenic - avian influenza (HPAI), which begun in late 2003 in several Southeast Asian countries and have now occurred in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, have been disastrous to the poultry industryand have raised serious global public health concerns. As o f February 2006, nearly 200 million domestic poultry had either died or beenculled, and economic losses to the Asian poultry sector alone are estimated at around $10 billion. Despite control measures, the disease continues to spread, causing further economic losses and threatening the livelihoods o f hundreds o f millions o f poor livestock farmers, jeopardizing smallholder entrepreneurship and commercial poultry production, and seriously impeding regional and international trade and market opportunities. The rural poor, who rely for a larger share o f their income and protein consumption on poultry, have been particularly hard hit with income losses and negative nutritional consequences. Between February and May, 2006, the first cases o f H5N1 (or H5) infections in poultry or wild birds were reported from an unprecedented 34 countries, marking the fastest and most extensive geographic spread of H P A I virus since the disease was first described in 1978. As o f June 25, 2006, OIE had received official notification o f the presence o f AI (H5) from 58 countries inAsia, Europe, Middle East, andAfrica.
2. So far, worldwide and even in South and Central Asia where many outbreaks have been observed, the H5N1 epizootic has only been associated with sporadic human cases. The available scientific evidence shows that the H5N1 virus i s not well adapted to humans yet. However, genetic accidents (mutation or recombination o f the H5N1 virus with the seasonal influenza virus) could trigger a pandemic. As of June 20, 2006 228 people have been infected by the disease in 10 countries, namely: Azerbaijan, Cambodia, China, Djibouti, Egypt, Indonesia, Iraq, Thailand, Turkey and Vietnam. Of the 228 people tested positive to H5N1, 130 died which means a fatality rate o f 57%. Before June 2006, no cases o f human to humantransmission had been formally confirmed. However, in June 2006 in Indonesia, an outbreak involved eight members o f a single family, and seven o f them died. The presence o f the H5N1 virus was confirmed in all eight. This i s the largest cluster o f human H5N1 ever reported. While the case is under further investigation, evidence is increasing for human-to-human transmission. The nature o f the virus and the recent increases in the number o f known cases o f avian influenza (AI) transmission have raised concerns over the potential emergence o f a pandemic, which could have devastating effects on human health and livelihoods.
3. It is impossibleto anticipate when the next influenza pandemic may occur or how severe its consequences may be. On average, three pandemics per century have been documented since the 16th century, occurring at intervals of 10-50 years. In the 20th century, pandemics occurred in 1918, 1957 and 1968. The pandemic o f 1918 is estimated to have killed up to 50 million people in eighteen months, with peak mortality rates occurring in people aged 20-45 years. The pandemics o f 1957 and 1968 were milder, but many countries nevertheless experienced major strains on health care resources. Ifa major pandemic were to appear again, similar to the one in 1918, even with modern advances in medicine, an unparalleled toll o f illness and death could result. Air travel might hasten the spread o f a new virus, and decrease the time available for
- 1 -  preparing interventions. Country health care systems could be rapidly overwhelmed, economies strained, and social order disrupted.

Romania has demonstrated full commitment in fighting AI and has shown good practice and efficiency in containing the disease and closing all outbreaks during both the first and the second AI wave. 2. Technical analysis
81. The Bank's appraisal mission, in collaboration with the AI technical lead agencies FAO, OIE and WHO, have found the technical design of the proposed project to be appropriate, addressing critical needs in the country's preparedness for influenza and other infectious diseases, and to be consistent with the GPAI program including its list o f eligible activities. The main issues are:
82. Animal Health:
(i)Institutional framework and contingency planning. In response to weaknesses identified during the first two waves o f AI outbreaks, the government has started to
- 30 -  restructure its key veterinary institutions and to enhance their capacity. In collaboration with local and international partners, the proposed project will support the institutional capacity enhancement in critical areas such as evaluation and restructuring o f institutions, establishment o f animal disease control centers, and contingency plan implementation guidelines and manuals. (ii)Monitoringandsurveillance. ThesecondwaveofHPAIoutbreaksinRomaniahas shown that the lack o f reliable epidemiological information, and the sound analysis thereof, has hampered the development o f rational, targeted disease control measures and slowed down the containment o f the disease. Veterinary capacity for monitoring, surveillance and epidemiological analyses is a critical factor in every AI control and eradication strategy. The proposed project will therefore enhance the capacity o f veterinary services in collecting and analyzing epidemiological data and performing risk assessments. (iii)Diagnostic capacity in national and regional laboratories. Romania'slaboratories are comparatively well equipped for standard analytical procedures, but exceptional work loads and highly specialized analyses cannot be performed at the requiredspeed or quality level due to the lack o f specialized equipment, reagents and other consumables. Speed is a critical factor in the control o f highly contagious diseases such as HPAI. The project will increase the diagnostic capacity o f national and regional laboratories with small goods and consumables, technical assistance and training, for which no other funding sources exist. (iv) Applied veterinary research. A Government Decision under preparation at the time o f project appraisal is to provide ANSVSA inthe near future with a new mandate for transboundary and zoonotic diseases research under the administration o f the Institute for Diagnosis and Animal Health, to be located at existing premises at Tulcea. Thematic focus, structural designs, and programs for the new applied veterinary research did not exist at the time o f appraisal.
(v) Quality control for veterinary medicinal products and infectious disease research. Romania does not currently have the capacity to fulfill its responsibilities inproviding sufficient quality control for vaccine imports and other veterinary medicinal products which includes the test o f vaccines in live animals. Experiments with highly contagious pathogens require a high-containment laboratory environment that does not presently exist. (vi) Animal disease information system. Outbreak information and epidemiological data is being reported through individual e-mail or fax communication, but there is no systematic filing and distribution o f this critical information. The project will support the establishment o f a country-wide information system, connecting local and national levels and relevant agencies and individuals, allowing real-time access to critical information for disease control.
(vii) Quarantine, culling, and disposal. Romania's large number o f small-holder poultry farms with sometimes as few as a dozen chicken per household (average: 20) dispersed across a large country pose a particular challenge for disease control

In order to increase the acceptability o f the measure, the project will finance the purchase and operation o f animal welfare acceptable COz containers. Appropriate disposal facilities don't exist at the village level, and the transport o f (potentially) virus-infected carcasses represents a particular risk o f spreading the disease even further. In this situation and for the purpose o f highly infectious poultry diseases, mobile incinerators have been found to be more appropriate than large rending plants. The project will establish appropriate disposal capacity at the local level in conformity with environmental, animal welfare, and human health standards and requirements. (viii)On-farm bio-security. Bio-security on commercial and backyard poultry farms is a critical factor in the prevention o f the spread o f infectious diseases. Especially the second outbreak wave has shown that bio-security i s particularly weak on Romanian poultry farms, given its large %age o f backyard and even urban poultry raising practices. Without improved on-farm bio-security, Romania will not be able to avoid future outbreaks o f AI or other infectious animal diseases. Recognizing that bio- security on poultry farms i s - primarily - the result o f managerial decisions and behavior, the project will support awareness campaigns and knowledge transfer activities, but also technical on-farm pilot projects for enhanced bio-security.

From October 2005 to April 2006, Romania adopted two different control measures in order to control the disease: stamping out (46 outbreaks) and zoning (7 outbreaks). During this period, 421,470 birds from 16,166 backyard premises were destroyed. In early M a y 2006, the disease reoccurred and the presence o f the HPAI was confirmed on M a y 14, 2006. The first outbreaks were detected in Codlea, Fagaras (Brasov county) in a commercial farm, SC DRAKOM SILVA SRL. This farm had more than 105,000 broiler chickens. On June 7, 2006, the total number o f outbreaks went up to 127. The outbreaks spread across 18 counties and also reached Bucharest. From M a y 2006, 210,470 birds from backyard premises and 764,865 birds from the commercial farms in Codlea (Brasov county) were killed.

4. Agriculture plays a key role inRomania's economy, its share inGDP being around 11-14%. In addition, agriculture continues to be the largest employer in Romania, accounting for more than 30% o f the labor force, most o f which are in subsistence agriculture. Poultry production i s widespread across the country, with the backyard holdings accounting for 70% o f Romania's total poultry production. The particular structural challenge lies inthe low bio-security standards o f smallholder poultry operations inherent in their fragmented structure and traditional poultry and livestock management practices. Typical household in Romania comprises chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese, swine, sheep and goats, cows and horses living in an immediate proximity. Keeping o f domestic animals, and especially poultry, i s extremely extensive in Romanian villages, which means that poultry, andparticularly ducks and geese, freely graze during the day. Poultry production inRomanian villages i s essential for the owners who, at the time, do not have any other alternative for keeping and housing their poultry. The poultry owners use the poultry for their own consumption, but there is also a live poultrytrade at the localmarkets.
5. As regards the commercial poultry production, this appears to be highly concentrated. According to the Romanian Poultry Producers Association, there are 15 large producers of poultry meat who hold about 60% o f the total domestic production. They rely on integrated establishments that autonomously produce broiler chickens and poultry feed, and have their own slaughterhouses. There are also 20 middle and 43 small producers, yielding 30% and lo%, respectively, o f the domestic commercial poultry output.
6. In2005 the total Romanianconsumption ofpoultry (self-consumption excluded) went upto around 375,000 tons, reflecting an increase by 19% as compared to the previous year. The consumers favored poultry to other meat, given its lower prices. Out o f the total poultry consumption, 220,000 tons were provided by the domestic producers (59%), with the domestic output o f poultry practically doubling from 2000. If production for self-consumption was also considered, the total domestic output o fpoultry could be estimated around 360,000 tons.
7. Overall, 2005 was considered as exceptional for the poultry industry, in spite o f the downward trends recorded towards the end o f the year, due to the HPAI. The poultry producers invested heavily in their production capacities in order both to meet consumers' demands and to comply with the new legal requirements. Yet, starting with the last trimester o f 2005, the Romanian poultry industry was marked by the effects o f the AI. According to the Romanian Poultry Producers Association, the losses caused by the disease totaled EUR 70 million. They were due to sales price drop, delays inpopulating farms and storage costs. The stocks o f poultry meat increased massively from about 5,000 tons in October 2005 to 20,000 tons at the end o f the year. Nevertheless, they dropped a couple o f months later, reaching 10,000 tons in February 2006. In spite o f these signs o f recovery, the M a y episode o f the AI brought about a very sharp decrease o f poultry meat consumption (by 50-80% duringthe first days o f outbreaks).
8. Responsibility for the ongoing surveillance and monitoring for the HPAI in poultry and migratory fowl and for response in case o f an outbreak rests with the National Sanitary, Veterinary and Food Safety Authority (ANSVSA). ANSVSA was established in 2004 as the main body in charge with the food safety and animal health, subordinated to the Romanian
- 38 -  Government and under the coordination o f the Ministry o f Agriculture, Forests and Rural Development (MAFRD). The Authority currently functions according to the provisions o f the Government Decision no. 130/2006. The Romanian Parliament authorized ANSVSA to be the contact structure with the European Food Safety Authority and to act on functional and decisional autonomy, according to the commitments made by Romania in its international relations. The ANSVSA services extend over 90,000 producers, processors and marketing units, to which approximately 2,200,000 individual holdings add. The human resources the Agency relies on include own staff, but also contracted veterinarians.
9. The Romanian veterinary services are provided both on a public and on a private basis. The public veterinary services are organized as a top-down system, covering the central, county and local levels. There are several bodies subordinated to the ANSVSA, who i s the central institution. On one hand, there are the 42 County Sanitary Veterinary and Food Safety Agencies (Bucharest included), which also incorporate the regional sanitary and veterinary units, and the local sanitary, veterinary and food safety units. On the other hand, there are three public institutions, acting in the veterinary field: (1) the Institute for Diagnosis and Animal Health (IDAH), (2) the Institute for the Control of Biological Products and Veterinary Drugs, and (3) the Institute for Veterinary Hygiene and Public Health (IVHPH). A2 ImprovingHPAI Preventionand ControlPlanning -
4. Contingency Plan Implementation Guidelines and Manuals. European Council Directive 2005/94/EC obliges every EU Member Country to draw up a national contingency plan specifying the national measures to be implementedin the event o f an outbreak. Romania as an
- 54 -  EUcandidate country therefore needs to design a national plan in accordance with the Directive provisions. Inthis plan and related manuals, detailed information must be given, inter alia, about the staff involved in control measures, their skills and responsibilities, as well as detailed instructions for staff with respect to reporting duties, field measures such as quarantining, culling and disinfection, location o f and access to equipment and materials, and personal protection against the potential risk o f infection. (B)StrengtheningDisease Surveillance, Diagnostic Capacity, and Research
B1- StrengtheningMonitoring and Surveillance Systems
5. Surveillance Capacity of Veterinary Services. Surveillance programs entail structured sampling approaches to search for evidence o f disease in animal populations. Examples include regular routine repeat serum sampling inregional or national populations or in sentinel flocks or in surveillance zones inan outbreak situation, and also continuous collection o f dead waterfowl to be examined for evidence of HPAI. The project will provide technical assistance and training for staff o f veterinary service institutions at national and county levels, focusing on the design and implementation o f HPAI surveillance programs, collecting and analyzing epidemiological data and performing risk assessments (support for serological testing under active surveillance schemes i s provided under the diagnostic capacity component B2). The project will also support transportation facilities and arrangements for surveillance field work as needed.
6. Epidemiological Surveys. European Council Directive 2005/94/EC (dated December 20, 2005) on Community measures for the control o f avian influenza and repealing Directive 92/40/EEC requires EU Member States (MS) to "ensure that epidemiological inquiries are started on the basis of questionnaires, established within theframework of the contingency plans providedfor in Article 62." These inquiries need to include, inter alia, the period o f infection on the premises, possible virus origin, identification o f contact holdings, and movement o f poultry and poultry products, persons, vehicles and other material. EU MS have the duty to inform the E C and other MS if the results o f the epidemiological inquiries suggest transboundary transmission of the virus. The second wave o f outbreaks in Romania, starting on M a y 11, 2006, has shown that the lack o f reliable epidemiological information, and the sound analysis thereof, has hampered the development o f rational, targeted disease control measures and slowed down the containment o f the disease. The project will provide technical assistance and training for epidemiological studies and surveillance programs to support continuously adapted and improved disease control measures. In Romania where 70% o f poultry i s produced in backyard
- 55 -  systems, small-scale and semi-commercial poultry production systems are the major control target.
B2 Strengthening Diagnostic Capacity -
7. Diagnostic capacity in Romania's national reference laboratory (IDAH) and county laboratories. Romania's veterinary diagnostic service is organized in the National Reference Laboratory (IDAH) and 41 regional laboratories. During the first outbreak o f H5N1 HPAI in Romania, diagnosis o f AI was performed by classical methods, i.e. virus isolation in chicken embryos, as well as detection o f specific antibodies through hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and imunodiffusion tests. IDAH recently adopted molecular diagnostic techniques that could speed up diagnostic procedure and process a large number o f samples on a daily basis. Currently, there are two Real-Time PCR machines, but the capacity should be further strengthened to process the required number o f samples that could arise if the virus spreads further. Eight regional laboratories adopted conventional PCR techniques. PCR techniques require specific and expensive reagents. Pathogenicity o f the isolated viruses i s currently determined in IDAH by genetic sequencing. The existing device i s a single capillary sequencer in which only a limited number o f samples can be processed daily. Purchasing a four capillary sequencer will increase IDAH's capacity for the determination o f pathogenicity o f isolated AI strains. Results obtained by this method may also be used for future applied veterinary research. Testing by ELISA o f serum samples collected on a large scale in surveillance programs will strengthen the diagnostics o f AI based on the detection o f specific antibodies. This method allows processing o f a large number o f samples within one day, but also requires specific and expensive diagnostic kits. IDAHandmost o fthe regionallaboratoriesare equippedto use ELISA. Methods that are already in use in Romania's veterinary diagnostic laboratories and those that will be adopted require basic protection equipment and training activities in order to prevent possible infection o f the laboratory staff with H5N1 HPAI. The equipment and activities should be in compliance with the respective appropriate biosafety standards.

C1 - TargetingVirus Eradicationat the Source
13. Quarantine, Culling and Disposal. Although capable teams are in place to effectively control H P A I outbreaks, the recent wave o f out outbreaks has overwhelmed authorities and veterinary services. The wide distribution o f small flocks across a country where 70% o f poultry are produced in backyard systems is a particular challenge for the control o f the disease. The project will contribute to the enhancement o f existing capacities for the control o f HPAI outbreaks as requiredby existing national contingency plans. Weaknesses have been identified in the areas o f quarantining (disinfection stations), culling o f infected and at-risk poultry, and the safe disposal o f poultry carcasses and potentially infectious materials in a bio-secure and environmentally acceptable manner. Disinfection practices will be improved with support from other than project sources. The project will focus its assistance on the culling o f poultry and on the disposal o f carcasses in small-holder systems - which dominate Romania's poultry sector. The project will finance the purchase and operation o f containers where C 0 2 i s applied in an animal welfare acceptable manner. C2 - SupportingVaccination Campaigns
14. Vaccination planning and implementation. Vaccination o f poultry against HPAI is a controversial issue but continues to be discussed as an option to contain HPAI outbreaks. The controversy stems from the possibility that vaccinated poultry may become infected without showing clinical signs and may consequently continue to excrete the virus into the environment. Moreover, infected domestic waterfowls seem to carry the virus without showing any clinical signs and therefore pose a major risk o f spreading the virus to other domestic poultry as masked carriers. Continuous infections and endemism could be the result. On the other hand, vaccination does increase the threshold for the infection, and if vaccinated birds become infected, they will excrete the virus ina significantly lower amount and during a shorter period o f time. Vaccination can be an effective tool in situations where other measures failed to control the infection and where the disease became endemic. However, to reduce the risk o f negative effects, vaccination
- 58 -  campaigns need to use vaccines that allow the distinction between infected and vaccinated animals and need to be accompaniedby appropriate surveillance schemes and restrictions.
15. Effectiveness o f vaccination in controlling H P A I in Italy i s well documented and recent experiences regarding vaccination in controlling H5N1 HPAI in Vietnam and China are also encouraging. Therefore, although vaccination against H P A I is generally prohibited inthe EU, the recent Council Directive 2005/94/EC considers that "Vaccination against avian influenza can be an effective tool to supplement disease control measures and to avoid massive killing and destruction o f poultry or other captive birds. Current knowledge suggests that vaccination may be useful not only as a short-term measure in emergencies but also as a long-term measure to prevent disease in situations o f higher risk of introduction of avian influenza viruses from wild life or other sources." The same Directive offers the option o f Emergency vaccination: "A Member state may introduce emergency vaccination in poultry or other captive birds as a short term measure to contain an outbreak when a risk assessment indicates there i s a significant and immediate threat o f avian influenza spreading within or into the Member State concerned in accordance with this Section where there is one or more o f the following: (a) an outbreak within that Member State; (b) an outbreak in a nearby Member State; or (c) where avian influenza has been confirmed inpoultry or other captive birds in a nearby third country" as well as Preventive vaccination: "Member States may introduce preventive vaccination in poultry or other captive birds as a long term measure in accordance with this Section where they deem that on the basis o f a risk assessment certain areas o f their territory, type o f poultry husbandry or certain categories of poultry or other captive birds or the poultry or other captive birds compartments are exposed to the risk o f avian influenza." Romania, as a candidate country, has a legal option for using vaccination against HPAI as an additional tool for controlling H5N1 in poultry. A policy on the use o f vaccination for the containment o f HPAIoutbreaks has not yet been formulated nor has a contingency plan for the practical the implementation o f a potential vaccination campaign been drafted.
16. The project will therefore provide technical assistance and training including orientation visits to other countries, to develop Romania's vaccination policy and action plan in the form o f detailed operational manual for vaccinations against HPAI, and train officials in the implementation o f vaccination campaigns and post-vaccinationmonitoring.
(D)ImprovingBio-securityinpoultryproductionandtrade
17. Bio-security on small-scalepoultry farms. After the first wave o f AI outbreaks inRomania which is believed to have been caused by wild birds inthe Danube Delta region, the second wave revealed that inappropriate farm management and trade practices can have equally dramatic effects on the spread o f the disease. However, most o f Romania's H5N1 HPAI outbreaks occurred inbackyard poultry systems where 70% o f the country's poultry are kept, revealing that bio-security on backyard farms is insufficient and represents a major risk for new waves o f infections. On these farms, a farm household typically keeps 20 chickens, 10 ducks, 5 turkeys, 3 geese, 3 swine, 10 sheep and goats, a cow and a horse living inimmediate proximity, sometimes roaming freely around the farm, adding to the risk o f both (i) mixing o f wild and domestic birds, and (i) species-to-species transmission and mutation or even recombination o f the virus. doc.repnme: Romania - Avian Influenza Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response (APL) Project
doc.abstracts: The Romania Avian Influenza Control and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response (APL) Project supports and constitutes an integral part of a national program to increase Romania's avian and human influenza preparedness. In this context, the overall development objective o f the project is to reduce the threat posed to humans and the poultry sector in Romania by Avian Flu and other zoonoses, and to support the preparation for, control of, and response to influenza pandemics and other infectious disease emergencies in humans. The project has three components each with multiple sub-components that support activities in prevention, preparedness, contingency planning, response, and containment. Component 1 focuses on animal health: it strengthens veterinary institutions; improves Avian Flu prevention and control planning; strengthens monitoring and surveillance systems, diagnostic capacity, animal diseases information systems, applied veterinary research capacity, and Avian flu control programs; supports poultry vaccination campaigns; and improves bio-security in poultry production and trade. Component 2 focuses on human health by enhancing Public Health Program Planning and Coordination; and Strengthening o f National Public Health Surveillance Systems and the health system's response capacity. Component 3 funds public awareness, communication, and implementation support.
